title: R43970
content: This report provides an overview of the actions taken by the Administration and Congress to provide FY2016 appropriations for trade-related agencies under the Commerce, Justice, Science, and Related Agencies (CJS) appropriations process. It also outlines the enacted FY2015 appropriations for the International Trade Administration (ITA), the U.S. International Trade Commission (USITC), and the Office of the United States Representative (USTR). President Obama signed the Consolidated and Further Continuing Appropriations Act, 2015 into law on December 16, 2014. The Consolidated and Further Continuing Appropriations Act, 2015 (P.L. 113-235) provided $61.753 billion for agencies funded by the CJS appropriations act in FY2015, including $600.8 million for three trade-related agencies. The Administration requested $66.382 billion for CJS for FY2016, 7.5% more than Congress appropriated for FY2015. For the three trade-related agencies, the Administration requested $684.6 million for FY2016, an increase of 13.9% over FY2015. The House recommended $597.8 million for FY2016, 12.7% less than the Administration's request. The Senate committee-reported bill recommended $601.8 million, 0.2% greater than FY2015 enacted amount and 12.1% less than the Administration's FY2016 request. President Obama signed the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2016 into law, providing $626.0 million for three CJS trade-related agencies. This amount is 4.2% greater than the FY2015 appropriation but 8.6% less than the Administration's request. The FY2016-enacted appropriation is 4.7% greater than the House recommendation and 4.0% greater than the Senate recommendation. The International Trade Administration (ITA) aims to improve U.S. prosperity by enhancing industry competitiveness, promoting trade and investment, and ensuring trade law compliance. ITA provides export promotion services, enforces trade agreements, administers trade remedies, and supports trade negotiations. In 2013, ITA underwent a major organizational change, consolidating units into Global Markets, Industry and Analysis, and Enforcement and Compliance. Additionally, the Executive and Administrative Directorate provides policy leadership. The International Trade Administration (ITA) is responsible for policy leadership, information technology support, and administration services. Budget amounts for ITA between FY2005 and FY2015 are shown in Table A-1. The FY2015 CJS Appropriations Act provided $462.0 million in direct funding, with an additional $10.0 million in user fees. The Administration's FY2016 request was $496.8 million, an increase of 7.5% over FY2015. The House recommended $457.0 million in direct appropriations for ITA, 8.0% less than the Administration's request. The Senate Committee on Appropriations recommended $463.0 million for ITA in direct funding, $1.0 million above the FY2015 enacted level, $33.8 million, or 6.8%, below the FY2016 budget request, and 1.3% above the House recommendation. The FY2016 appropriation for ITA is $483.0 million, with an additional $10.0 million in user fees, for a total of $493 million in available funds. ITA's Global Markets unit combines country and regional experts, both overseas and domestically, and specific trade promotion programs to provide U.S. firms with country-specific export promotion services. The Global Markets unit of ITA provides U.S. firms with export promotion services, market access advocacy, and investment destination promotion. It engages with foreign governments and businesses to advance U.S. commercial interests, resolve market barriers, and advocate for U.S. firms. ITA requested $334.4 million and 1,122 full-time employees for FY2016, an increase from the previous year. ITA's Industry and Analysis unit aims to enhance U.S. industries' competitiveness through trade and investment policies. It facilitates market access for U.S. businesses and administers programs supporting small and medium-sized enterprises. For FY2016, ITA requested $58.3 million and 248 FTEs for this unit, a slight increase from the previous year. The ITA's Enforcement and Compliance unit enforces U.S. trade laws, promotes antidumping measures, addresses trade-distorting practices, and advocates for U.S. industries. For FY2016, ITA requested $80.7 million and 348 FTEs, an increase from the previous year. USITC is an independent agency with investigative responsibilities related to international trade. The USITC administers U.S. trade remedy laws, provides independent analysis on tariffs and trade, and maintains the Harmonized Tariff Schedule. Its activities include investigating dumped and subsidized imports, conducting safeguard investigations, and adjudicating disputes on intellectual property rights. The agency serves as a federal resource for trade data and policy information, providing analysis to Congress, the President, and USTR to develop U.S. trade policy. The USITC plays a key role in U.S. trade policy by providing independent analysis and maintaining trade data. Its budget request for FY2016 was $131.5 million, with the House recommending $86.5 million and the Senate Committee on Appropriations recommending $84.5 million. The USTR, responsible for developing U.S. international trade policies, had a FY2016 appropriation of $88.5 million, 32.7% less than the Administration's request. It negotiates trade agreements, resolves disputes, and leads FTA negotiations like the TPP. The USTR is leading negotiations for the T-TIP and monitoring existing FTAs. The FY2015 CJS Appropriations Act provided $54.3 million for USTR. The Administration's FY2016 request was $56.3 million and 240 FTEs, a 3.7% increase. The House recommended $54.3 million, 3.6% less than the request. The Senate committee-reported bill recommended $54.3 million. The Senate Committee on Appropriations recommended consolidating USTR into the Department of Commerce. The FY2016 appropriation for USTR is $54.5 million, slightly higher than the FY2015 amount and lower than the Administration's request. Congress has funded specific trade-related programs under CJS agencies, addressing China trade enforcement, trade promotion, and the Interagency Trade Enforcement Center. Some of ITA's funding has been dedicated to antidumping and countervailing duty enforcement activities since 2004. China Compliance was established in 2004 under the Consolidated Appropriations Act to enforce U.S. antidumping and countervailing duty laws. The FY2016 appropriation for China antidumping and countervailing duty enforcement was recommended at $16.4 million. The ITA's China Countervailing Duty Group was created in FY2009 to handle duties on imports from non-market economy countries. The FY2016 appropriation includes $16.4 million for China antidumping and countervailing duty enforcement and compliance activities. SelectUSA, part of ITA's Global Markets unit, coordinates investment-related resources across federal agencies to promote the United States as an investment market. ITA requested $20.0 million for FY2016 for the SelectUSA program, with the Senate Committee on Appropriations recommending up to $10.0 million for the program. The FY2016 appropriation includes $16.4 million for China antidumping and countervailing duty enforcement and compliance activities. SelectUSA, part of ITA's Global Markets unit, coordinates investment-related resources across federal agencies to promote the United States as an investment market. President Obama signed Executive Order 13601 to establish the ITEC for advancing U.S. foreign trade policy through strengthened enforcement of trade rights. The ITEC is led by a Director designated by USTR and a Deputy Director designated by the Secretary of Commerce. The Interagency Trade Enforcement Center (ITEC) coordinates trade enforcement matters among various government agencies. It works closely with the International Trade Administration (ITA) to address economic issues. The FY2016 budget request for the ITEC was $15.0 million, with the Senate Committee on Appropriations recommending up to $10.0 million. Issues that Congress may have considered while debating the FY2016 funding levels for the three CJS trade-related agencies included approving a one-time 55.6% increase in funding for USITC, consolidating commercial and trade-related agencies for efficiency, providing additional funding for ITA's SelectUSA program and ITEC, and continuing funding for ITA's China antidumping and countervailing duty enforcement activities.
